The development of efficient non-precious metal catalysts is crucial for the large-scale application of hydrogen production via water electrolysis. Coupling FeNi catalysts with transition metal chalcogenides has proven to be an effective strategy for enhancing catalytic performance. However, limited attention has been given to simultaneously regulating electronic structure and local environmental factors. In this work, we synthesised Fe-Ni-C and NiSe heterostructures, that leverage enhanced water adsorption and rapid electron transfer at their surfaces. Among them, NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 exhibits excellent catalytic performance, requiring low overpotentials of only 276 mV for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and 292 mV for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) reaching to 10 mA·cm−2 in 1 M KOH. Moreover, it exhibited remarkable stability, with no significant degradation observed during 12 h of constant potential stability testing. Simulation calculations show that NiSe increases the water adsorption capacity at the Fe-Ni-C interface on the OER reaction process on the metal catalyst surface at the microscopic level. It regulates the orbital overlap between Fe and Ni above the Fermi energy level, and effectively reduces the adsorption energy of electrolytic water reaction intermediates of Fe-Ni-C. This strategy of constructing heterojunctions between bimetallic catalysts and transition metal sulfides modulates the electronic structure and enhances the surface water distribution, which contributes to improving the reactivity of electrolytic water catalysts. This study further deepens the design and understanding of bimetallic catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalysts Density functional theory Nickel selenide OER Water splitting Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the increasing severity of global energy and environmental challenges, the development of clean and renewable energy sources has become a critical global priority [1,2]. Water electrolysis is a safe and sustainable hydrogen production method, offering a convenient pathway for industrial hydrogen generation [3–5]. However, the sluggish reaction kinetics of traditional materials result in high overpotentials, posing significant challenges to commercial applications [6]. Although noble metal materials exhibit excellent catalytic activity for water electrolysis, their scarcity and high cost severely hinder their commercialization. Therefore, the development of abundant, efficient, and stable non-noble metal electrocatalysts is of paramount importance. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of highly ordered porous materials [7] with unique structural advantages, high porosity, large specific surface area, and tunable functionalities and sizes [8]. These properties make MOFs valuable for applications such as adsorption, energy storage [9], and catalysis [10]. However, their poor conductivity limits charge transfer efficiency, and the small pore sizes hinder mass transport, making MOFs typically serve as sacrificial templates to control nanostructures [11]. For instance, Li et al. [12] used dual-template ZIF-8@ZIF-67 to encapsulate Fe-EDTA, producing Fe-CoS2/carbon nanotube composites (Fe-CoS2/CNT-CPs). The incorporation of CNTs acted as electronic transmission pathways, while the synergistic effect of Co and Fe bimetals yielded an optimized overpotential of 293 mV at 10 mA·cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Such templates are versatile for synthesizing various porous carbon/metal oxides, metal sulfides, and metal phosphides, offering excellent catalytic and energy storage properties [13–16]. Constructing heterogeneous interfaces is an effective strategy to enhance the activity of electrocatalysts [17]. Ye et al. [18] utilized CoMo layered double hydroxide (LDH) as a precursor, which was subsequently transformed into a MOF and phosphorized to construct a nanoflower-like Mo-doped cobalt phosphide/nickel phosphide heterostructured array (Mo-Co2P/Ni12P5). The incorporation of MOFs improved the porosity and active surface area of the electrocatalyst. The presence of multiple heterointerfaces and synergistic effects between transition metals facilitated rapid charge transfer. Consequently, the synthesized Mo-Co2P/Ni12P5 exhibited promising bifunctional electrocatalytic performance for HER (η100= 209 mV) and OER (η100 = 333 mV). Zhou et al. [19] fabricated a heterostructured electrocatalyst composed of crystalline Co-MOF and amorphous Co-S nanosheet arrays aligned on a carbon cloth CC substrate (denoted as Co-MOF/Co-S@CC) via a rapid sulfidation method. The synergistic interaction between the MOF-derived heterostructure and the nanosheet array architecture endowed the Co-MOF/Co-S@CC sample with enhanced electronic conductivity, more exposed active sites, larger reaction area, shorter mass transport pathways, optimized electronic configuration, and superior mechanical robustness. As a result, the Co-MOF/Co-S@CC electrode delivered exceptional bifunctional HER and OER performance in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, requiring low overpotentials of 64 mV and 217 mV at 10 mA·cm−2, respectively. Wang et al. [20] developed a novel heterostructured catalyst, NiSe₂-NPs/NiMoNNRs, by confining NiSe2 nanoparticles onto NiMoN nanorods. This catalyst demonstrated efficient bifunctional catalysis (HER and OER) in alkaline media, achieving overpotentials of 58 mV and 241 mV at 10 mA·cm−2 for HER and OER, respectively. Under solar-driven conditions, it attained a solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency of 18.4 %, highlighting the role of heterointerface engineering in optimizing electronic structures and boosting catalytic activity. Strategies such as altering composition and size, surface or interface modification, and introducing conductive supports effectively enhance catalytic activity [21–25]. Wang et al. [26] prepared a novel Ni3S2@Co(OH)2 heterostructure via a combination of hydrothermal and electrodeposition methods. Benefiting from the synergy between individual components and interface engineering, the heterostructure exhibited overpotentials of 110 mV and 257 mV for HER and OER at 10 mA·cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH. Similarly, Guo et al. [27] synthesized MoSe2@NiSe2 hollow core-shell spheres via hydrothermal selenization of Ni MOFs with Mo, achieving enhanced stability. MoSe2 prevented the aggregation and sintering of NiSe2 nanoparticles, and the synergistic effect of bimetallic sites significantly boosted HER activity in 0.5 M H2SO4, delivering a low overpotential of 187 mV at 10 mA·cm−2 and excellent stability over 40 h. Wang et al. [28] developed a controlled pyrolysis method to fabricate a NiCo/Fe3O4/MOF-74 nanocatalyst for efficient OER in alkaline media. Leveraging the porous structure of MOFs and the interaction between metal/metal oxide particles, the hybrid catalyst achieved a remarkable overpotential of 238 mV at 10 mA·cm−2, showcasing exceptional catalytic performance. Based on the previous work [29], we found that the unique catalytic activity is attributed to the binding of iron and the construction of heterogeneous interfaces. Notably, NiSe demonstrated excellent electrochemical properties, but with high conductivity and low limiting current, the overpotential is still high or there is a lot of room for improvement. The low limiting current may be partially attributed to the diffusion resistance of water or insufficient local water availability at the reaction interface. Inspired by these findings, a class of materials, Fe-Ni bimetallic site catalysts (Fe-Ni-C) materialswere investigated, which exhibit excellent conductivity and have been reported to process good OER activity [30,31]. However, prior studies have predominantly focused on the intrinsic properties of these catalysts, with limited attention given to the kinetic changes induced by the introduction of inhomogeneous interfaces. Herein, we present a MOF-derived FeNi bimetallic site catalyst integrated with NiSe heterostructures via high-temperature calcination and a solvothermal method. The NiSe/Fe-Ni-C interface optimizes charge redistribution, achieving a low HER overpotential of 292 mV and OER overpotential of 276 mV at 10 mA·cm−2. Molecular dynamics (MD) and density function theory (DFT) calculations reveals enhanced electron transfer at Fe/Ni sites reduces energy barriers for water dissociation. The catalyst maintained good activity and achieved excellent performance in bifunctional water electrolysis after 12 h of stability testing in an alkaline electrolyte. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Hydrochloric acid was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Vulcan XC-72 carbon black powder was purchased from Vicbio Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Ferric nitrate hexahydrate (Fe(NO3)2·9H2O, 99 %), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99 %) homobenzoic acid (98 %), potassium hydroxide (KOH, 85 %) and commercial platinum flakes (99.99 %) were purchased from Aladdin. Hydrazine hydrate (50 %) was purchased sigma-aldrich. N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, 85 %) was purchased from Macklin. All the reagents were used without further purification. The laboratory water is deionized water. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe-Ni MOF (Fe-Ni-C) A total of 135 mg of ferric nitrate hexahydrate and 233 mg of nickel nitrate hexahydrate were weighed and added along with an appropriate amount of trimesic acid to 30 mL of DMA solution. The mixture was ultrasonicated for 20 min to obtain a clear solution. The solution's pH was adjusted to 5 by the dropwise addition of hydrochloric acid. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL autoclave and reacted at 150 °C for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed three times with anhydrous ethanol, vacuum-dried at 60 °C for 3 h to obtain Fe-Ni MOF. Fe-Ni MOF-derived materials (Fe-Ni-C) were prepared via calcination in a tube furnace under an N2 atmosphere. The temperature was increased at a rate of 5 °C·min−1 from room temperature to X °C, followed by a 2-hour hold at the target temperature. The resulting products were designated as Fe-Ni-C@X (X = 400, 600, 800, corresponding to the calcination temperatures). 2.3 Synthesis of Fe-Ni MOF derivative loaded NiSe composites (NS/Fe-Ni-C) A total of 0.2 g of selenium powder, 0.4 g of nickel acetate tetrahydrate, and an appropriate amount of Fe-Ni-C@X were added to a 50 mL hydrothermal autoclave liner. Subsequently, 10 mL of deionized water, 15 mL of anhydrous ethanol, and an appropriate amount of hydrazine hydrate solution were introduced. The mixture was stirred for 10 min before sealing the autoclave and reacting at 160 °C for 36 h. After cooling to room temperature, the product was repeatedly washed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol and vacuum-dried at 60 °C for 6 h to obtain nickel selenide composite materials. The resulting materials were denoted as NS/yFe-Ni-C@X (where y = 1, 2, 3, corresponding to Fe-Ni-C@X masses of 0.05 g, 0.1 g, and 0.15 g, respectively). 2.3 Material characterization The sample composition and crystalline properties were analyzed through X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 advance) using Cu Kα radiation. The diffraction angle ranged from 5 to 90°, with a scanning rate of 5°·min−1 and a step size of 0.02° The catalyst morphology and chemical composition were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Nova450) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Further characterization of the catalyst's composition, crystal structure, and chemical composition was performed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM 2100F). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Kalpha), with Al Kα radiation as the source, was employed to analyze the elemental composition and oxidation states on the catalyst's surface. All sample data were calibrated using C 1 s at 284.8 eV. In addition, the elemental composition was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) with an Agilent 5110 spectrometer. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All measurements were conducted on a CS350H electrochemical station (Wuhan Corrtest Instruments Corp., Ltd.) equipped with a conventional three-electrode system in 1 M KOH electrolyte. The working electrolyte was a catalyst-coated glassy carbon electrode, reference electrode was an Hg/HgO electrode, and counter electrode was a platinum sheet. To prepare the catalyst ink, 4 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in a solution containing 720 μL of ethanol, 240 μL of deionized water, and 40 μL of 5 wt % Nafion solution. The mixture was then sonicated for 30 min to ensure uniform dispersion. A 12 μL ink of the resulting solution was then applied onto a 3 mm glassy carbon electrode and allowed to dry, forming the working electrode. The OER performance was tested using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) at a scan rate of 5 mV·s −1, and Tafel plots were obtained from polarization curves. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed at frequencies ranging from 105 to 0.01 Hz with an AC amplitude of 5 mV. Double-layer capacitance was derived from cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves obtained at different scan rates (20, 40, 60, 100, 120 mV·s −1). All electrochemical test data were calibrated using the Nernst equation: (1) E v s . R H E = E v s . H g / H g O + E v s . H g / H g O θ + 0.059 × pH ( pH = 14 ) Where, E v s . R H E is the potential of working electrode which is relative to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), E v s . H g / H g O is the measured potential of work electrode versus Hg/HgO electrode, E v s . H g / H g O θ is the potential of Hg/HgO electrode which is relative to standard hydrogen electrode, and last term represents the potential of RHE at certain pH of electrolyte. 2.5 Theoretical calculations The MD and DFT calculations were conducted within Materials Studio 2020. Further details on theoretical calculations can be found in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion MD simulations provide microscopic insights into the structural and kinetic properties of aqueous solutions, offering a deeper understanding of the kinetic nature of experimental studies. To investigate the interaction between the electrolyte and catalyst surfaces, we constructed computational models of KOH adsorbed on carbon (KOH/C), KOH on Fe-Ni-C (KOH/Fe-Ni-C), and KOH on the NiSe/Fe-Ni-C heterostructure (KOH/NS/Fe-Ni-C). These models (Fig. 1 a) reveal the role of local water microenvironment regulation and electronic structure modulation in enhancing catalytic performance. The MD simulations provide valuable insights into the mass transfer phenomena of the catalyst during water electrolysis. These simulations were carried out using a solid-liquid interfacial model with a random distribution of initial water molecules in the NVT system at 298 K (see SI for details of the calculations) [32]. The kinetic trajectories movies are provided in the Supporting Information (moive 1, moive 2). The films illustrate that the model reflects the interactions between H2O molecules in solution well and accurately describes the dynamics of H2O molecules on the catalyst surface. Fig. 1b visually illustrates the enhanced water-splitting performance of Fe-Ni-C, highlighting its improved catalytic efficiency and reaction kinetics. Fig. 1c provides a comparison of the relative concentration distributions of the three systems, meaning the average concentration of water molecules along the z-axis of the 3D model. The concentration distribution of H2O on the Fe-Ni-C surface is higher than that on pure carbon, confirming its superior hydrophilicity. Conversely, the introduction of NiSe on the surface does not have much effect on the distribution of H2O, reflecting that NiSe does not affect the superior hydrophilicity of Fe-Ni-C. The bonding interactions of Fe sites (Fe-Ow) and Ni sites (Ni-Ow) with water molecules in the Fe-Ni-C interface were analysed by radial distribution functions. Fig. 1d-e show that the peak positions of the radial distribution function (RDF) curves of the two models are basically the same, which indicates that the adsorption distances between water and the Fe-Ni-C interface did not change significantly as a result of the introduction of the new interface. However, the g(r) peaks of both sites increased significantly after the addition of NiSe interface, which reflected the enhancement of their water adsorption capacity for the bimetallic catalysts. The peaks of RDF curves of Fe sites were more obviously enhanced after the addition of NiSe interface [33]. Furthermore, these MD results are further corroborated by the contact angle measurements provided in the supplementary materials. This finding suggests that the Fe sites possess a heightened water adsorption capacity, and the augmentation of Ni sites does not result in their predominance. This further substantiates the notion that Fe-Ni-C belongs to the category of bimetallic synergistic catalysis. 3.1 Structural and morphological characterization Fig. 2 a shows the synthesis of NS/Fe-Ni-C. The SEM image of Fe-Ni MOF (Fig. 2b) reveals that the overall Fe-Ni MOF was stacked together in a spherical shape with an uneven surface, where petal-like folds appear to be distributed across the spheres. In addition, N2 adsorption-desorption tests (Fig. 2c) were performed on Fe-Ni MOF in this study, and it is found that the specific surface area of Fe-Ni MOF was about 926 m2·g−1, with an average pore size of 3.93 nm, consistent with previously reported results in the literature. After high-temperature annealing the Fe-Ni MOF, the Fe-Ni-C retains part of the pore structure, which is favorable for the active sites. The SEM images of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 (Fig. 2d, Fig. 2e) show that, the catalyst adopts a three-dimensional coral-like morphology. Notably, the NiSe crystals appear as nanoparticles that are loaded onto, embedded within, and encapsulated by Fe-Ni-C@600. The intimate integration between NiSe and Fe-Ni-C@600 contributes to the formation of this distinctive structure. The EDS images (Fig. 2f, Fig. 2 g) of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 show that the elements of Fe, Ni, and Se were uniformly distributed on the surface of the catalysts, and a small amount of aggregation exists in the C elements are present in a small amount of aggregation. The composition and crystal structures of Fe-Ni MOF, Fe-Ni-C@600, and NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 were analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Fig. 3 a). For Fe-Ni MOF, diffraction peaks appear at 2θ values of approximately 6.8° and 10.6°, consistent with previously reported results for Fe-Ni MOF [34,35]. After annealing Fe-Ni MOF in an N2 atmosphere at 600 °C, Fe-Ni-C@600 was obtained. The XRD pattern of Fe-Ni-C@600 exhibits no extra diffraction peaks and reveals a distinct Fe-Ni alloy structure, as the high-temperature annealing process removes other components, leaving only the metallic and carbon framework. Characteristic peaks at 43.7° and 50.9° correspond to the (111) and (210) planes of FeNi alloy, as indexed in the FeNi PDF#97–063–2913, while a weak peak at 26° indicates the presence of carbon in Fe-Ni-C@600. For NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600, the XRD results show characteristic peaks near 32.8°, 44.4°, and 49.8°, corresponding to the (101), (102), and (110) planes of NiSe, as indexed in PDF#97–064–6521. The absence of additional peaks confirms that the catalyst primarily contains NiSe crystals. TEM images of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 (Fig. 3b) reveal that NiSe nanocrystals are uniformly distributed within the catalyst and closely integrated with Fe-Ni-C@600, forming a distinct heterointerface. The HRTEM image (Fig. 3c) shows two sets of lattice fringes with spacings of 0.27 nm and 0.20 nm, corresponding to the (101) and (102) planes of NiSe, respectively, which is consistent with the XRD results and confirms the successful incorporation of NiSe crystals. Compared to Fe-Ni-C, the XRD pattern of NiSe/Fe-Ni-C exhibits an additional peak at approximately 32.8°, corresponding to the (101) plane of NiSe, as indexed in PDF#97–064–6521. This suggests that the (101) plane of NiSe is the exposed crystal plane in the composite system. The exposed (101) plane provides more active sites during water electrolysis reactions, making it the preferred crystal plane for catalytic simulations (Fig. 3d). The surface elemental composition and valence state variations of the samples were further investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The survey spectrum of Fe-Ni-C@600 (Fig. S1) confirms the presence of Ni, Fe, C, N, and O elements in the catalyst. For NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600, the survey spectrum reveals the additional presence of Se, attributed to the formation of NiSe. This is accompanied by an increase in the peak area of Ni 2p, while other peaks remain consistent with Fe-Ni-C, indicating the robust heterojunction formation between NiSe and Fe-Ni-C [36]. The Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 3e) shows binding energies at 710.83 eV and 723.93 eV, corresponding to Fe2+, at 713.28 eV and 726.38 eV, corresponding to Fe3+, and at 706.39 eV and 719.99 eV, corresponding to Fe0 [37–39]. The Ni 2p spectrum (Fig. 3f) exhibits binding energies at 852.05 eV and 869.56 eV for Ni0, at 855.65 eV and 872.85 eV for Ni2+, and satellite peaks at 861.39 eV and 878.88 eV [40,41]. The observed Fe0 and Ni0 peaks suggest the formation of an FeNi alloy during the composite preparation process [42]. The high-temperature annealing of Fe-Ni MOF to produce Fe-Ni-C leads to a degree of nitrogen-doped carbon formation, as confirmed by the high-resolution N 1 s spectrum (Fig. S2). This spectrum reveals four deconvoluted peaks at 398.90, 400.04, 400.84, and 401.8 eV, attributed to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N, respectively [43]. A high proportion of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N in Fe-Ni-C facilitates electrocatalysis by modulating the electronic structure of carbon. Pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N can act as metal ion donors through coordination bonds [44], indicating that metal ions play a more pronounced role than carbon atoms in influencing charge transfer within the system. High-resolution XPS analysis reveals that, compared to pure Fe-Ni-C, the Fe 2p spectra of NS/Fe-Ni-C exhibit negative binding energy shifts, while the Ni 2p spectra show positive shifts. This indicates a reduction in the electron density of Ni, with more electrons transferred to Fe sites. Analysis of the charge density before and after compositing (Fig. 5b, Fig. 5c) suggests that electron transfer does not occur directly across the Fe-Ni-C interface but is primarily driven by the NiSe interface. The significant electron transfer between NiSe and Fe-Ni-C forms a strong charge redistribution at the reaction interface, synergistically enhancing water-splitting efficiency. 3.2 The electrochemical performance of the catalyst The electrocatalytic properties of catalyst composites were tested under alkaline conditions (1 M KOH, 25 °C) using a standard three-electrode system to evaluate their performance in both OER and HER. The OER is equally critical in evaluating the performance of water-splitting catalysts. A comparison of the LSV curves of NS/Fe-Ni-C with different precursor ratios (Fig. S3, Fig. 4 a) reveals that NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 exhibited the best OER catalytic activity, with an overpotential of only 276 mV. This value is significantly lower than those of Fe-Ni-C@600 (316 mV) and RuO2 (328 mV), indicating that the incorporation of NiSe with Fe-Ni-C@600 greatly enhances the OER catalytic performance. Fig. 4c shows that the Tafel slopes of Fe-Ni-C@600, NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600, and RuO2 are 77 mV·dec−1, 81 mV·dec−1, and 141 mV·dec−1, respectively. The notably lower Tafel slope of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 compared to other catalysts suggests faster OER kinetics. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements (Fig. 4e) reveal that the charge transfer resistance (Rct) of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 is 6.7 Ω, much lower than that of Fe-Ni-C@600 (17.4 Ω). This reduced Rct value demonstrates faster charge transfer for NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600, consistent with its superior OER overpotential results and one of the primary reasons for its excellent OER catalytic activity. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of the catalysts was assessed by calculating the double-layer capacitance (Cdl). Fig. S4 shows the CV curves of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 in the non-Faradaic region (−0.3 V to −0.2 V) at various scan rates (20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 120 mV·s −1). The plot of the current density difference (∆j/2) against the scan rate (Fig. 4 g) yielded Cdl values of 1.14 mF·cm−2 for Fe-Ni-C@600 and 0.032 mF·cm−2 for NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600. The significantly lower Cdl value for NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 suggests higher intrinsic catalytic activity [45]. To evaluate the HER electrocatalytic activity of the catalysts, LSV was performed in 1 M KOH solution. Fig. S3 illustrates the LSV curves of NS/Fe-Ni-C with different precursor ratios. Among them, NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 exhibited the lowest HER overpotential, requiring only 292 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA·cm−2. As shown in Fig. 4b, Fe-Ni-C@600 demonstrated HER catalytic activity with an overpotential of 334 mV. After NiSe loading, the overpotential was further reduced by 42 mV, highlighting the enhanced catalytic performance. The Tafel plots (Fig. 4d) revealed that the Tafel slopes of Fe-Ni-C@600, NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600, and Pt/C were 203 mV·dec−1, 171 mV·dec−1, and 110 mV·dec−1, respectively. A lower Tafel slope for NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 indicates faster reaction kinetics compared to Fe-Ni-C@600. EIS data (Fig. 4f) shows that the charge transfer resistance values for Fe-Ni-C@600 and NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 is 23 Ω and 19 Ω, respectively. The lower Rct value of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 indicates faster charge transfer, attributed to the strong interaction at the heterointerface between NiSe nanocrystals and the Fe-Ni-C structure. This interaction facilitates the free electron transfer between Fe and Ni atoms, optimizing the overall electronic structure of the catalyst. The synergistic effect between the Fe-Ni-C and NiSe interfaces effectively reduces the catalyst's charge transfer resistance. The stability of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 was evaluated through durability tests. After 5000 CV cycles, the HER overpotential of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 increased by only 18 mV, as shown in Fig. 4i, indicating good stability. Additionally, during a 12 h constant-potential polarization test at −1.216 V, the current density showed negligible decay, further confirming the excellent stability of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 throughout the testing process. 3.3 DFT calculations analysis To elucidate the water splitting mechanism of NiSe/Fe-Ni-C in alkaline electrolytes, DFT calculations were conducted to explore the intrinsic synergistic interactions between NiSe and Fe-Ni-C. In an alkaline environment, water molecules undergo adsorption and dissociation at active sites via the HER or OER pathways. For the HER mechanism, the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG(*H-*OH)) serves as a key descriptor for the Volmer step, reflecting the catalyst's ability to activate water molecules. The subsequent Tafel or Heyrovsky steps are assessed using the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen intermediate adsorption (ΔG(*H)), as illustrated in Fig. 5 e. Theoretical analysis reveals that the heterointerface between NiSe and Fe-Ni-C enhances water activation and optimizes hydrogen intermediate adsorption/desorption kinetics, thereby improving catalytic performance [46]. Charge density distribution slices (Fig. 5a) and charge population diagrams (Fig. 5b–c) indicate that the incorporation of NiSe significantly reduces the charge density on Fe atoms, enhancing surface reactivity and facilitating intermediate desorption. This aligns with XPS results, which show a shift in the Fe 2p binding energy. Density of states (DOS) analysis (Fig. 5d) for NiSe/2Fe-Ni-C@600 reveals a rightward shift of the D-band center, leading to higher antibonding state occupancy below the Fermi level, thereby optimizing the electronic structure and catalytic activity. Comparative HER studies between Fe-Ni-C and pure NiSe (Fig. S5) demonstrate that while NiSe excels in water dissociation, Fe-Ni-C alone exhibits limited activity. The formation of the NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 heterointerface significantly lowers the water dissociation energy barrier of Fe-Ni-C from 1.13 eV to 0.4 eV. For *H intermediates, the adsorption energy barrier at Fe sites decreases from −0.22 eV to −0.11 eV upon NiSe incorporation (Fig. S5), confirming Fe sites as favorable active centers for *H adsorption and H₂ formation. Furthermore, DOS analysis (Fig. S6) indicates that Fe-Ni-C exhibits a higher density of states above the Fermi level, resulting in stronger *O intermediate binding and elevated OER energy barriers. Adsorption Evolution Mechanism (AEM) is the most classical and widely studied reaction mechanism in OER [47,48], which is based on the adsorption and gradual oxidation process between the metal active sites and the reactants. Step 1: Hydroxide ions (OH−) are adsorbed on the metal sites, which lose an electron and the hydroxide ions are oxidised. This step is the initiating step of the reaction where the oxidation state of the metal site is increased and the adsorbed hydroxyl intermediate (*OH) is formed. Step 2: The intermediate *OH further loses a proton (H⁺). The metal site again loses an electron and the hydroxyl intermediate is further oxidised to the oxygen intermediate (*O). Step 3: Another hydroxide ion or water molecule undergoes a nucleophilic attack on *O. The metal site loses another electron, leading to the further oxidation of the oxygen intermediate and the formation of a peroxide intermediate (*OOH). Gibbs free energy calculations for the OER pathway (Fig. 5f) identify *OOH formation as the rate-determining step (RDS), with an overpotential of only 0.14 eV at Fe sites, confirming the superior OER activity of NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600. Step 4: The *OOH intermediate undergoes another electron transfer and proton-coupling process. The metal site loses its final electron, fully oxidizing the peroxide intermediate and ultimately releasing oxygen. This step marks the final release of O₂, after which the metal site returns to its initial state, ready to participate in the next catalytic cycle.The incorporation of Fe decreases the energy barrier of the rate-limiting step in the OER, enabling sustained reaction progress. Collectively, these findings demonstrate that the NiSe/Fe-Ni-C heterostructure optimizes both HER and OER pathways through electronic modulation and interfacial synergy, enabling efficient alkaline water splitting. 4 Conclusions In summary, a NS/Fe-Ni-C catalyst with an interfacial water-rich microenvironment was designed and synthesized by MD and density functional theory. Compared to a pure carbon interface, Fe-Ni-C exhibits superior hydrophilicity, while the introduction of NiSe, further enhances water adsorption at metal sites and increases the local water molecule density at the Fe-Ni-C interface. This combined heterojunction strategy of bimetallic catalysts and NiSe significantly enhances electron transfer rates, thereby improving the reaction kinetics for water splitting. This study explores the advantages of interface engineering from the innovative perspective of molecular dynamics simulations, offering a microscopic insight into the kinetic properties of the catalytic surface, which further complements experimental investigations. The results demonstrate that Fe-Ni-C exhibits stronger hydrophilicity compared to pure carbon interfaces, and the introduction of the NiSe interface, with additional catalytic sites, further enhances the water adsorption capability of the metal sites at the Fe-Ni-C interface. Notably, the optimal NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 improved HER performance by 12 % over the original bimetallic catalyst. The OER activity was improved by 17 %, which is superior to the commercial RuO2. Furthermore, the catalyst maintained stability during 12 h of constant potential testing. The NiSe interface reduces the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates during water splitting on the original bimetallic site catalysts interface, adjusts the orbital overlap of Fe and Ni above the Fermi level, accelerates electron transfer, and enhances electrocatalytic activity. The proposed interfacial engineering approach and charge transfer mechanism in bimetallic site catalysts have been shown to facilitate a deeper understanding of the synergistic mechanisms of components at the heterojunction interface. Among them, the concept of Fe-Ni-C as the active centre, and NiSe electronically regulating and optimising the local water microenvironment to improve electrolytic water kinetics, has the potential to enhance the design of electrolytic water catalysts from multiple perspectives, thus providing a valuable reference point for further research. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient non-precious metal catalysts is crucial for the large-scale application of hydrogen production via water electrolysis. Coupling FeNi catalysts with transition metal chalcogenides has proven to be an effective strategy for enhancing catalytic performance. However, limited attention has been given to simultaneously regulating electronic structure and local environmental factors. In this work, we synthesised Fe-Ni-C and NiSe heterostructures, that leverage enhanced water adsorption and rapid electron transfer at their surfaces. Among them, NS/2Fe-Ni-C@600 exhibits excellent catalytic performance, requiring low overpotentials of only 276 mV for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and 292 mV for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) reaching to 10 mA·cm−2 in 1 M KOH. Moreover, it exhibited remarkable stability, with no significant degradation observed during 12 h of constant potential stability testing. Simulation calculations show that NiSe increases the water adsorption capacity at the Fe-Ni-C interface on the OER reaction process on the metal catalyst surface at the microscopic level. It regulates the orbital overlap between Fe and Ni above the Fermi energy level, and effectively reduces the adsorption energy of electrolytic water reaction intermediates of Fe-Ni-C. This strategy of constructing heterojunctions between bimetallic catalysts and transition metal sulfides modulates the electronic structure and enhances the surface water distribution, which contributes to improving the reactivity of electrolytic water catalysts. This study further deepens the design and understanding of bimetallic catalysts.
